notes: Doubt cast on the persistent rumors of poisoning by Livia.
Some suggestion of Caligula's possible involvement, but support does not seem strong.
Competing narratives, but Suetonius claims death following a fever during travel. https://anastrophe.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/perseus/citequery3.pl?dbname=LatinAugust21&query=Suet.%20Tit.10&getid=1
Manner of death is a matter of considerable dispute; there being an apparent lack of consensus, the death of Gordian III is recorded as unknown here.

Sources suggesteither  death in battle or a post-battle assassination by his own soldiers. It seems reasonable in either case to categorize the context of his death as  being associated with the battle.
The immediate cause of death is unclear, but sources agree on placing it in the context of his captivity.

McMahon casts doubt on the problematic Historia Augusta's description of death associated with illness. Early Byzantine sources claim assassination. https://www.livius.org/sources/content/zosimus/zosimus-new-history-1/zosimus-new-history-1.63/
Various sources appear to agree on a death by natural causes, though they appear to be especially distant from his time. https://www.jstor.org/stable/41536200
Sources appear to agree on a disease-related death. https://www.jstor.org/stable/26788257

The accounts by Eusebius and the like are obviously idealized, but the general notion of Maxenitus having died during the rout at the Battle of Milvan Bridge does appear to be the consensus. https://ia803409.us.archive.org/6/items/ecclesiasticalhi1850euse/ecclesiasticalhi1850euse.pdf#page=435&zoom=auto,-316,434
Strong support appears lacking for a specific manner of death.
Name originally rendered as 'Lucinius I' in original dataset sourced for this project; it has bee amended to 'Licinius I' here and in the final illustration.

record_author: Walter E. Roberts; Michael DiMaio, Jr.

notes: Roberts suggests suicide as the likely manner of death.
